comments.text:
+Casper Christensen read my comment. You can have holes all over a lens as

them act as 1 gigantic one

comments.author: Casper Christensen

comments.text:
Both are important to "clarity". The diameter directly impacts the angular 
resolution (larger effective diameter == higher zoom) while the capture 
area directly impacts the SNR (larger area == more signal). For stellar 
radio sources SNR isn't as big of a concern, though for observing a planet 
that isn't as "bright" on its own SNR can't be overlooked.

Try an interferometer. This is essential several smaller telescopes spread 
out over a distance to function as a far larger telescope. Coordinating 
several telescopes spread out over say several AU, Astronomical units, the 
distance of Earth from the Sun, or 1 AU = ~93M Miles. Now you have the 
hyper huge telescopes you need to resolve planets in detail a whole galaxy 
way, or just a few stars over.﻿

+1 Note: While this works in theory, a lot of light is scattered and lost 
as it travels through space. No matter how big or good the interferometer, 
it will never be able to recover what's lost. So even if you build a huge 
telescope to watch World War II as it happens from 75 light years away, 
most of the details will be lost (things that happen inside buildings, 
covered by dust and clouds, blurred by the atmosphere, light absorbed by 
stellar matter).

No. 2 small mirrors don't equal a larger one. Each single one of those 
telescopes would attain a crappy image, not a single great image. To attain

wouldn't work.

single image what you get are 2 separated images, 1 in each mirror.

Not necessarily: just because a set is infinite, doesn't mean that that set 
contains every single possibility. Take for instance the set of all even 
numbers. This set is infinite, yet contains not a single uneven number. 
Thus, even though the multiverse theory predicts an infinite amount of 
possible universes, doesn't necessarily mean that it contains every single 
possible universe. And yes: I'm fun at parties! ;)

emporor - without needing to discuss everything with the senate. That's why 
he staged the clone wars. This authorization gave him the ability to 
control everything, even transforming the republic into an empire. He 
originally promised to put those authorizations down after the war, but he 
didn't. Just like the roman empire started.
And even if they had the choice, do you really think the senate, the 
imperial guard, the police, the people and the PRIVATE ARMY of Palpatine 
would be totally okay with the Jedi taking their trusted leader prisoner? 
What do you think was the purpose of Order 66? Just that! It would look 
like a take over by the Jedi which was feared at that time. "Yeah, sorry, 
we're just taking your elected leader away, because he's possibly a 
powerful demonic mastermind and part of  an evil religion that didn't exist 
for the last couple of millenias. We don't know exactly and we have no real 
prove, but we figure that out later, okay?"
Imagine a few policemen trying to arrest the president like that. Even if 
they had a reason and HAD to act, they would be stupid to do it publicly.

"I'm asking you to listen to it in hopes that you'll see some things you 
haven't seen before."

So you basically want me to stop enjoying the movies and become as 
overcriticizing and nitpicking as other so called "fans". Say what you 
want, that is propaganda.

"How can you claim to be right when you won't even listen to the points in 
the review?"

I'm not saying I'm right. That is because there is no right or wrong here. 
I'm also not saying you're wrong, just that it doesn't really matter that 
much and that all this hatred against the prequels is ridiculously 
exaggerated and ANNOYING! It's only nitpicking. No logical error could ever 
make that seem reasonable, although haters won't stop trying. There are far 
worser movies out there that never got so much hate or reviews that go into 
meticulous detail on what could possibly be another reason to dislike 
them.Wouldn't it be Star Wars and wouldn't "fans" have romanticized 
memories of the  originals, nobody would care. Proof that it's just about 
being butthurt, because the new series just isn't the "right" one. Screw 
the next generation of Star Wars fans, all they should know is how bad 
everything is.

When I watch the prequels I don't think much about little logical errors 
that may or may not be in there. I just enjoy them.  Apparently that IS 
possible. How can it be wrong to enjoy a movie? Not you and not some 
youtube reviewer has the right to determine what's ultimately a good movie 
and what's a bad one. They are either invidually liked or not. And what you 
are trying to do here is propaganda, say what you want. I don't know why 
you want me to stop enjoying the prequels, but all the more I won't watch 
this review. You won't watch Episode 1 with an open mind or think about my 
arguments either, so we're even.

And now I'm clicking on ignore. I said everything I have to say more than 
once, so I'm done here.

Why was it neccessary for Vader to freeze Luke or Han in carbonite again? 
Is securing and paralyzing for transport not enough anymore? No, both where

comments.text:
+RewindDawg Technically the rate is not constant... or rather, the rate of 
expansion of space itself is constant and uniform, but the relative 
velocity of any object receding from us due to this expansion is NOT 
constant, it increases with distance (and andromeda is relatively close)... 
This is what accounts for the acceleration as you look further out, because 
ALL of space is expanding uniformly, and the more space between two 
objects, the more expanding space there is between those two objects... The 
blowing up of a balloon analogy is actually the best one... At a constant 
rate of expansion, you will see that the relative distance between two dots 
drawn close to each other on the balloon's surface will increase more 
slowly than the distance between two dots further apart on the balloon. The 
further away the dots are from each other, the faster they will move away 
from each other. 

The 'faster than light' really only refers to what is going on at the edges 
of the observable universe, and comes from the fact that if you just look 
at the relative speed of objects, once you start looking at objects of 14 
billion light years away or so, you start seeing this expansion showing 
redshifts that indicate the things moving away from us at close to (or at) 
the speed of light... Really you can infer this already because we can only 
see things up to about 14 billion LY away, and thus, we posit that what we 
can see of the universe is 14 billion years old... That would mean that 
over the lifetime of the observable universe, the stuff at the 'edges' (the 
furthest we can see, anyway) has in fact moved away from us at a relative 
velocity effectively averaging at the speed of light. Since the rate of 
expansion is increasing, and is not limited based on relative distance, 
this means that the stuff we can see at the edge will be moving away faster 
than the speed of light relative to us... This means that as time goes on, 
we will be able to see less and less objects in the sky, as the stuff at 
the very edge of our vision keeps accelerating faster until it is moving 
away fast enough that the light coming from them can no longer go fast 
enough to reach us. Basically, our effective 'horizon' of visible objects 
will slowly shrink.  

Really, for all we know, there could be a lot more of the universe that is 
further away... It really could be infinite, or at least much older than 14 
billion years old, but we just can't see that because of the expansion 
effect that could already have stuff that far away moving at a relative 
velocity high enough that it is outside of our 'horizon'... The furthest we 
can see is also the furthest back in time that we can see.

Yeah, it's called redshift. Much simpler.
 There's a whole gamut of things that could be debated. Unless you 
understand GR and are comfortable with Tensor Calculus there's no way I can 
show you proof mathematically. Even GR is looking more and more like it may 
need revision. But where people get this idea about the Universe expanding 
faster than light is beyond me. We can't even agree on the value of lamda 
(cosmological constant) which directly influences that very thing. Then 
there's the unresolved galactic outer rotation business which ushered in 
the ad hoc notion of dark matter, which there is no direct evidence for 
contrary to popular belief. MOND is a much more elegant theory to explain 
away dark matter and energy but time will tell I'm sure.

captions.text:
Hey Vsauce I'm Jake and if Star Wars were
to have happened in our universe and truly

occurred a long time ago in a galaxy far, far
away ... light from the actions in Star Wars

could be hitting Earth right now, or will
some day. So if we pointed a telescope at

the right far away galaxy .... could we see
Star Wars? Even if we choose the nearest spiral

galaxy to us, Andromeda, the requirements
and results for resolving individual planets,

people or ewoks turns out ... to be almost
as disappointing as the Phantom Menace.

To make out the flag on our moon from earth
we would need a telescope that's 260meters.

If we wanted a clearer picture, one that
would show us the stripes, if they were still

there, we would have to bump the size up to
6,850.

The biggest optical telescopes on Earth have
mirrors around 10meters and the largest one

planned, the aptly named European Extremely
Large Telescope, will be completed in 2022

and have a 39 meter mirror. Still a good deal
smaller than you would need to see the flag
on the moon.

When you try and see small objects that are
good distances away, especially when they

have less light, it becomes much more difficult
to resolve. For example, here is the best

photo we have of Pluto, and this is a celestial
body in our own solar system and relatively
close at 4.2 billion km.

So the reason we can take an amazing image
of Andromeda, 2.5million light years away,

is because we are looking at an object that
is an estimated 260,000 light years across

and contains a trillion stars. It has to do
with the relative size to distance where Andromeda

would be .1 or 200,000 times greater than
Pluto's.

If we wanted to be able to see a planet or
satellite in a completely different galaxy

like Andromeda, you would need a pretty substantial
telescope. To be able to get a glimpse at

the forest moon of Endor, more than double
the size of Pluto we would only need a telescope

that was 6...wait for it... million 500 thousand
kilometers in diameter. About the size of
4.5 of our suns.

But we want to actually see what is happening
on the planet. I mean, I want to look at an

Ewok with my own eye because they are adorable.
To produce a fairly detailed image we would

need something gigantic, something 1.7 light
years large. This telescope would surpasse

Voyager 1's current 18 billion km distance
and would be larger than our solar system.

But here is when we run into a slight problem.
Bad Astronomy has a great piece about pointing

Hubble at Earth and trying to get a photo.
The resulting image would be blurry because

of how quickly it is orbiting. He likens it
to "trying to take a picture from a moving

car: nearby objects will streak by, but far
away objects appear to be moving slowly."

So even though Andromeda is spatially far
away, it is magnified to such a degree that

we'd probably get a very blurry Ewok. The
incredibly long exposure time the telescope

would need to collect enough photons to form
an image wouldn't help either and whatever

image we were able to produce would have a
blue hue since Andromeda is moving so quickly

towards Earth, at a rate of 300km a second,
that the light is blueshifted.

Even light coming from people near you has
to travel a distance. Since lightspeed is

finite, at arms length you're actually seeing
a person 3 nanoseconds younger than they really

are. There is a constant flow of new, old
light being spread out across the Universe

so who knows what we might be able to see
next, maybe a galaxy far, far away.
And as always, thanks for watching.
